B0006399FS|4.0|First of all, I'm sick and tired of people just flat out bashing an album or a band just for the sake of bashing. This goes for all you who have blasted this album and band with words like \\"suck,\\" \\"sold out,\\" and all the other colorful and wonderfully original insults written by folks who think they are music connoisseurs just because Amazon.com gives them free access to write out a review. U2 are brilliant musicians (and you, dear friend, are NOT!). There's a reason they've lasted as long as they have. There's a reason they're called \\"legends.\\" There's a reason Bono is as acclaimed and admired as he is -- worldwide!  Bono's voice and lyrics are second to none in the present day music world and his \\"messiah complex\\" personality is what makes him one of the all time greatest front men in rock history. And for those of you who claim they've \\"sold out\\" -- since when have U2 claimed to be an \\"underground band?\\" Look up the term in context to pop culture before you use it so liberally!  Since \\"New Year's Day\\" the band has been on the radio and on television. And while so-called great bands have come and gone through the 80's, 90's and the Present -- U2 remains. Deal with it! <br /> <br />Secondly, to bash this album is ridiculous. Is it as good as Joshua Tree or Achtung Baby? Of course not. Bands aren't supposed to churn out 'masterpieces' every time they release an album. So, let's look at this album for what it is: an album. A good album at that. Greatest of all time? No. Just as brilliant as (fill in the blank)? No (The same nimrods who blasted Achtung Baby when it first came out as \\"not the same U2 as Joshua Tree, Unforgettable Fire, etc.\\" are probably the same idiots who are blasting this album today). Just shut up and enjoy the moment. Some of these reviews are written as if U2 made a J-Lo album! Relax. The U2 of the present will never be like the U2 of the 80's. U2 simply set out to do what artists do: they composed an album that speaks their minds and, along theway, hope that it resonates with fans.  <br /> <br />So, instead of bashing one of the all time greatest rock bands, stand back and appreciate a talent like this band is still among us. In a world where the music industry churns out Ultra-Crap like Linkin Park, Limp Bizkit, all the \\"emo\\" bands, and all the regurgitated nonsense (we are living in the worst era of music), be grateful a band like U2 still exists. This album is not great, and it is unfair to place it next to Joshua Tree and other albums like it. But it is a good album. A good piece of music to listen to. And it proves that even a \\"good\\" U2 album is greater than all the other junk that saturates the airwaves.  <br /> <br />Bottom line, U2 is forever linked to the all time greatest bands. Even the Beatles had \\"Magical Mystery Tour\\" and Led Zeppelin had \\"In Through the Out Door.\\" Yet we consider these bands as pillars in the history of rock and music. U2 stands along side these giants.  <br /> <br />Those who deny that are simply unhappy, cynical, sad wretches still looking for the glories of the past. Do us all a favor, you Gollums of the Review Board: Stay in the shadows grumbling over how everything sucks and keep it to yourself. <br /> <br />I understand this sounds like a pretentious, U2 apologetic, review. But I had to say something.  <br /> <br />Anyway, the album is pretty darn good.  <br /> <br />Now Vote 'YES\\" above and thanks for your time!
068987474X|3.0|There are some who find this book empowering, enlightening, liberating and virtually indispensable. The authors produce some entertainment and score some points but the bottom line is that this book is a shallow, manipulative tome, written by people from the equally shallow \\"Sex and the City\\" TV show. It basically depicts men as immature or untrustworthy, and women as virtuous creatures who only need wake up and smell the coffee and deal with the jerks accordingly. This is standard recycled fare and the authors manipulate it to the hilt for their mostly female audience. The fact that it is a man \\"revealing\\" this advice doesn't make it any less a retread. Now let's get down to bidniss.      1) IS HE NOT GETTING INTO YOU BECAUSE HE IS A JERK OR IS IT BECAUSE YOU YOURSELF AIN'T THAT HOT? Pandering to the mostly female audience, the authors hail female virtue and goodness versus male immaturity and perfidy. Those who play this game get more book sales, hence they dare not raise a key issue- He may not be into you, not because he's \\"a jerk\\" but because your opinion of yourself is hopelessy inflated and what you have to offer may not be that great relatively speaking. It is of course \\"politically incorrect\\" to raise such blunt questions despite all the blurbs about \\"honest\\" talk. It may be better for women to take an honest look at themselves, and what they bring to the table (it may not be all that impressive), rather than knee-jerk blaming of men for not being interested or commited enough.       2) HURT FEELINGS? WELCOME TO THE CLUB AND QUIT WHINING. NOW YOU KNOW HOW MEN FEEL: Much drama is expended on such \\"inconsiderate\\" male behavior as failing to return phone calls or e-mails. Curiously the level of female concern for \\"feelings\\" doesn't reach the same fever pitch when THEY treat men rudely and inconsiderately. Non-returned phone calls or e-mail? This is old news for many men as they are scornfully dismissed by women without a shred of common courtesy. It is unknownwhy females should expect any more consideration in 2005, when they do not see fit to extend the same to males (who are just supposed to accept it and \\"move on\\"). Proponents of so-called \\"simple\\" male needs fail to see that men don't like being rudely discarded, ignored or mocked, as is so prevalent in popular culture including the writer's own \\"Sex and the City\\" show.  Flash- they too are human. Again, many women need to quit whining and examine their own behavior in this regard. Do unto others..      3) WHY IS FEAR OF COMMITMENT \\"BAD\\"? Much anger is flung at perfidious males who keep hesitating rather than plunging into commitment. But why is this a bad thing? It is exceedingly wise these days for a man to proceed VERY CAUTIOUSLY before making commitments. With a high divorce rate and women initiating almost 70% of all divorces, men have learned the hard way about betrayal and that the supposedly \\"deeper\\" female \\"commitment\\" is also a shaky thing. In the divorce culture a man can expect little mercy from a system arrayed against him- one quick to ruthlessly squeeze him for the last penny, and quick to provide an array of subsidized public services to females, but a system quite cavalier when it comes to enforcing his rights in such areas as visitation, or in providing him institutional support.     Furthermore, the old breadwinner model is long gone- females are doing quite well in numerous fields and are paying their own way. Yet they unhesitatingly seek to assert control over the resources a man brings to the table, during and after marriage. No sane man would leave himself so exposed without taking a long, hard look at the woman pressing for \\"commitment\\". It may be that despite inflated female opinions, the investment package required in the female is not commensurate to the return.  In addition, matters such as religion, family objections, previous relationships, ethnicity etc. etc are quite valid reasons to cause commitment hesitation. It is not a matter offailing to return a phone call, or the so-called \\"not into you\\" as the \\"real\\" reason explaining male delay. The book's level of analysis on this count appears weak and shallow.       4) WHY IS MALE EFFORT TO SPARE FEMALE FEELINGS \\"CRUEL\\"? The book shows males reluctant to bluntly and harshly dump females. Instead they withdraw slowly, trying to avoid confrontation and spare female feelings. Yet this is seen by many as \\"players\\" at work. Why? Avoiding confrontation and sparing feelings are supposed to be among those kinder, gentler, celebrated \\"female\\" traits. So when a man does it he is a monster or a \\"playa\\"? Why the double standard? Would women really prefer a bluntly honest 2-minute breakoff of relationships since men are supposed to be more \\"direct\\"? The book doesn't say. Furthermore women play exactly the same game when they want to phase out or cool down a relationship- they ALSO let it linger, fail to return phone calls, etc.. Again, why is this fine for women but when a man does it he is a \\"jerk\\"? The authors claim to be \\"keeping it real\\" but they carefully avoid such questions.      5) \\"EMPOWERING\\" WOMEN OR PLAYERS? The book claims that the information \\"revealed\\" will help \\"empower\\" women. This might well be for some, but there is a level of naivete to this claim. True players have little to fear from this book. All they have to do is merely make their game more convincing on the surface- like returning phone calls more promptly, and murmuring the right commitment boilerplate. But once their objectives are achieved, the game is over. Women may feel \\"empowered\\" to break off at this point, but since the playa has already made his score, female \\"empowerment\\" just makes his dumping job easier. This book actually helps cut the playas workload. Indeed, since so many women are familar with this book, the playa need not go through an extended withdrawal period. All he has to do is start the process, and sure enough, the newly enlightened and empowered women will seize on the \\"signals\\" and will do the dirty breakup work themselves. Another added benefit is that she will go away feeling better and empowered, and also will take the onus for the break, while he is free to move on.     Readers, don't be fooled by the author's happy talk about \\"empowerment\\". Consider that it came from people writing for the \\"Sex and the City\\" TV show- a dubious fantasy land of $700 designer dresses and painless \\"relationships\\" bearing little relation to the hard realities of the street. There are better books than this shallow one such as Why Men Marry Some Women and Not Others- by John T. Molloy

0140177396|5.0|I started this book in high school thinking that is was going to be boring, a stereotypical classic.  When I finished it, my thoughts about it were totally different.  The enthralling story takes place on a dusty California ranch, with a wide variety of characters.  Steinbeck uses the most descriptive language I have ever seen an author use.  His writing not only describes to you the setting, but it also puts you in it.  To show more proof to you kids who think this is still a boring classic, behold: swearing!  Steinbeck does not hold back in language; this is to show a large amount of emotions, as well as to give the story a flair. <br />This is the story of two men's friendship, which they hold, despite handicaps and obstacles that block their way.  A surprising ending caps off the story as a very, very good book (no wonder all the adults like it).  Also, it's a short read: only a little over a hundred pages.  Believe me, you'll like it.

Outta Control - Club song. Good beat by Dr.Dre and some ok lyrics from 50 but they're still not really about anything new. 7/10    9. Get In My Car - Very nice song. Funny lyrics and a good beat. 50 has the ability to be humorous but doesn't choose to do so very often. 9/10     10. Ski Mask Way - This sounds like a song Biggie would have done (but better). Good beat, hook and lyrics but nothing outstanding. 8/10     11. A Baltimore Love Thing - Great song. Very creative of 50 to rhyme as heroin to the addict. Good lyrics and beat. 10/10     12. Ryder Music - OK song. Nothing really to this one other than a slow beat and some slow rhyming from 50. Catchy but not great. 6/1013. Disco Inferno - I don't like this song. It's so generic and definately a radio-friendly song. 5/10     14. Just A Lil Bit - Ugh. That chorus is annoying and seems to make up 90% of this song. Nothing new from 50...again. 4/10     15. Gunz Come Out - Good song. Dre provides a nice, dark beat while 50 rhymes over it with lyrics of violence and guns but after the last 2 songs, it's welcome. 8/10     16. My Toy Soldier - Pretty good. Yayo provides a good verse and 50's pretty tight. 7/10     17. Position Of Power - Nothing that stands out here but it's not bad. Go ahead and give it a listen. 7/10     18. Build You Up - Supposedly Jamie Foxx sings on this but you can't really tell that it's him. Kind of an annoying beat and a forgettable song. 6/10     19. God Gave Me Style - This isn't that bad. 50 decides to take time away from his guns to give God a shout out to thank him for making 50 so great. 7/10     20. So Amazing - Do not listen. I don't know how 50 can insult Ja's songs and then make a horrible song that Ja would make. This is awful, talk about hipocrisy. I don't know what 50 was thinking. Olivia takes over for Ashanti on the annoying chorus that goes on forever and 50 rhymes about nothing. 2/10    21. I Don't Need Em - Very nice song. Good beat and rhymes to (sort of) end the album. Not very long but still a good song. 9/10      22. Hate It Or Love It Remix - The original version is better with just 50 and The Game but with Banks, Yayo, and Buck, it gets too crowded and they just force in short verses. 8/10    Summary - Disappointing
B00005OWEG|5.0|Apocalypse Now Redux is NOT a sequel to Apocalypse Now- it is really the director's cut of Apocalypse Now. It was released in 2001- and the orginial was released in 1979. This version is just as good as the orginial, adding in 49 minutes of additional footage- and the footage is described below:    -The extended version of the scene where Willard (Martin Sheen)meets up with Kilgore (Robert Duvall)- Director Francis Ford Coppola makes a cameo in this scene.    - A new scene of Kilgore rescuing a child.     - Scene with aircraft bombing the treeline has been extended and has new effects.    - Scene showing Kilgore giving Lance (Sam Bottoms) new swim shorts and Willard stealing Kilgore's surfboard  and then it shows Willard and the Navy guys hiding from Kilgore's choppers.     - Scene with the Navy guys admiring their Playboy mags.     - Scene showing Willard talking about Dilantenes.    - A 10 minute sequence of Willard and the Navy guys finding 2 Playboy playmates and Chef (Frederic Forrest) and Lance having sex with them.     - After Clean (Laurence Fishburne)'s death- this is the most famous new footage- the 25 minute French Plantation sequence- featuring Christian Marquand and a whole bunch of other actors. This scene consists of Willard finding the French people, Clean's funeral, dinner with the French people (during this part of the sequence- the French told Willard how they felt about the war- which is what made this version of the film better.) And, Willard having sex with a French widow named Roxanne (Aurore Clement).     - The last of the added footage shows Colonel Kurtz (Marlon Brando) reading an article to Willard.    Words cannot describe the brilliance of this film. Ok, lets put it this way. This film holds a tie as the greatest war film ever made (with Steven Spielberg's Schindler's List (1993)) No one should miss this film. Nobody. This film is a classic and will remain a classic.    Overall rating: 10/10

B000001DVD|5.0|Unleashed on the buying public in 1981, this is the Lep's sophomore release. The album features a striking cover by Hipgnosis (these guys were EVERYWHERE during the 70's and 80's). Produced by John \\"Mutt\\" Lange (of AC/DC fame), this record is an improvement from their first release, but they are still trying to get out of the shadow of AC/DC.  Do they succeed, or do they try to cash in on the AC/DC sound? Here are my reviews of the songs based out of 5 *****:<br /><br />\\"Let It Go\\" - Wicked guitar intro introduces the melody and song. A thick, thumping bass kicks in followed by Joe's vocals and surging guitars.  Joe sounds great!  A fast paced rocker that hits on all cylinders.  Nice harmonizing during the bridge, and then the song kicks into overdrive.  A furious guitar solo. Joe has some great wails.  A great hard rock tune.  \\"So stop your stallin' and your bitchin'\\"! Perfect! Classic! This song received alot of FM airtime and was a modest hit for the band.  Rating - *****<br /><br />\\"Another Hit And Run\\" - Starts with a midtempo guitar, but builds steam as the bass and drum kick in. Strong bass from Rick Savage (this song was co-written by him).  Strong vocals from Joe Elliott.  Another rocking guitar solo from Clark and Willis (sounds alot like Angus Young of AC/DC).  A great song with tempo changes and a catchy melody.  A very good tune.  Rating - *****<br /><br />\\"High-N-Dry(Saturday Night)\\" - Opens with guitar intoducing the melody followed by drum and then Joe's vocals.  Bass and rhythm guitar then help drive the song into AC/DC territory.  Joe again shines on this song with some great singing.  Cool lyrics help make the song a winner. Great beat! Many a times I was indeed high-n-dry on a Saturday night! This was another hit for the band that received alot of airplay.  A true classic!  Rating - *****<br /><br />\\"Bringin' On The Heartbreak\\" - The biggest hit of off this album. A ballad ala Scorpions \\"Still Loving You\\" (definitely NOT AC/DC).  Strong chugging guitars and bass help to make this a hardrock tune.  A very nice guitar solo from Willis and Clark.  Joe really sings with alot of emotion \\"NO! NO! NO OOO!\\".  Another terrific rock-n-roll song.  Great!  Rating - *****  Leads directly into:<br /><br />\\"Switch 625\\" - An instrumental (written by Clark).  Has some nice vocal harmonizing as well as very thick bass and galloping guitar. A pretty decent instrumental as far as these things go.  You don't get bored listening to it. Would make a great song if there were lyrics written for it.  Rating - ***<br /><br />\\"You Got Me Runnin'\\" - Power chords to open the song (AC/DC big time) followed by a thumping bass line and \\"Hey hey hey\\" from Joe.  Strong rhythm helps give it a hardrock feel.  Great vocal harmonizing by the band really helps to give it a poppy feel.  The great vocal harmonizing is what separates them from AC/DC and the other 'metal' bands at the time. Guitar solo is blistering (sounds way too much like Angus Young). Joe once again sounds great.  Rating - ****<br /><br />\\"Lady Strange\\" - An unheralded gem of a song.  I really love the way Joe sounds on this cut.  Strong rhythm and bass helps lay a solid foundation for the vocals and harmonizing. A great, haunting melody really gives this song some color. Joe does some of his finest singing.  A very fast bridge really kicks the song up a notch. A very solid guitar solo. A fantastic song!  Rating -*****<br /><br />\\"On Through The Night\\" - I can't understand why this wasn't on their first album, but it's fine with me because this song ROCKS! Joe has a voice made by the rock-n-roll Gods!  He can't help but turn anything into a rockin' treat. A fast paced rocker. Tempo slows during the bridge but picks up into a galloping speed.  Cool guitar solo.  Once more a GREAT song! Rating - *****<br /><br />\\"Mirror, Mirror(Look Into My Eyes)\\" - Guitars introduce the melody and a strong, thumping bass comes next followed by Joe's vocals.  Joe again is great here.  A fantastic rhythm.  Strong, insistent. ANOTHER flat out great song.  Rating - ****<br /><br />\\"No No No\\" -  Punk meets hardrock!  A very fast paced hard slammin' song.  Easily the heaviest song on the album.  Drums are very predominant as well as the strong bass by Savage.  Sounds a litle like Judas Priest during the chorus (maybe Victim of Changes).  Furious guitar solo!  Joe really belts it out here!  Ends with a repeating \\"NO NO NO NO..\\"<br /><br /> Joe's screaming \\"NO\\" at the end of the album lets us know that they are NOT AC/DC clones!  Sure they have elements of AC/DC that are very obvious but that's not a bad thing!  Def Leppard is able to take that sound and give it their own twist with their very strong vocal harmonizing and melodies.  Overall, this was a CLASSIC, TERRIFIC, MINDBLOWING second release. The inside credits for the album gives a \\"Special thanks to Phil Collen\\".  This is interesting because Mr. Collen would take the place of Pete Willis during the recording of Def's next album. Also, Mr.\\"Mutt\\" would have an even bigger influence on the Lep's sound for their next album.  Was this a good thing or not?  See my review to find out.\\"No No No\\" -  Punk meets hardrock! B00070Q8DQ|5.0|Thickly layered, punishing sound. Blastbeats, monstrous grooves, symphonic chords and a seething wall of vocals - like a heavier, tighter, scarier version of Morbid Angel. Behemoth doesn't have to rely on overt displays of technicality like hyperactive time changes or weird polyrhythms - they take a more simplified approach with their song structures, each part a sonic bludgeon of sheer brutality. That's not to say there aren't incredible displays of technical ability by all, but that's not the sole reason for the existence of these songs. Each has its own theme, its own identity, its own place within the overall flow of the album. It's not at all like death metal in the style of Suffocation or Internal Bleeding - nor is it  black metal by any means. Demigod is a synthesis of the two, essentially death metal with black metal overtones. The closest comparison is Morbid Angel, but that is really a weak comparison at best. Behemoth sounds a thousand times heavier, and there's none of the pointless filler that seems to litter every Morbid Angel album. Anyone who likes death or black metal should own a copy of Demigod - it's one of those rare epics that's destined to be a classic for all time.

0786868694|3.0|I read all the reviews of this book with interest - Nigella certainly creates polarised responses - people either LOVE her or hate her.  This was the first Nigella book I bought, and on the whole I have enjoyed it.  However, in general, my experience of buying celebrity cookbooks is that I end up with a lovely book that I take great pleasure in reading many times (and drooling over the photos) but on the whole don't make a great deal of the recipes.  I think we buy these books because of the celebrity, their personality, their style and approach to food, not necessarily for a useful recipe resource.  We buy them for the beautiful pictures (and the beautiful people), for the stylish layout, and yes...for the expansive white spaces too.  Wise up people!  Realise this fact, and don't expect the books to be more than what they intend to be - ENTERTAINING. <br /> <br />Now, for some comments for and against the book: <br /> <br />So far I've made the Pumpkin & Seafood Curry (great), the Asian Spiced Kedgeree (again, great, but needed more fish sauce than she suggested) and the Hot and Sour Soup (great).  I have found the recipes easy to follow, quick to put together and lovely to eat. <br /> <br />While there are several recipes on my to-make list (seems to be a general consensus that the Lemon Risotto and Chocolate Cloud cake are fantastic), on the whole, I would say that in total I probably would never make more than about 15 of the recipes in the book.  Quite frankly, many of them simply don't appeal to me (Ham in Coca Cola?  May sound kooky and kitsch, but I think it's  disgusting quite frankly!  The Liptauer looks like congealed vomit, as does the bagna cauda....)  Having said that, this does not mean that I didn't enjoy reading about them - Nigella's saving grace is precisely her style and approach to food - her witty and charming prose makes this book a pleasure to read, whether or not you actually make the food.  Her relaxed and practical advice (e.g. substitutewhatever you've got in the pantry) mixed with her uncompromising love for cooking as a relaxing activity (e.g. references to the joys of 'stoveside pottering', or how the mindless repetitive stirring of a risotto can ease stress, or for entertaining \\"remember that it's not a test of your worth and acceptability: it's just dinner\\") result in, for me anyway, an inspiring read. <br /> <br />My main gripe would be that the book uses both book weight and volume measures - this is a bit annoying - consistency would be better (and my choice would be volume measures all the time).   <br /> <br />One more - the idea of providing 2 pages per section for notes is good in principle (I'm an avid adder of notes), but I think 2 pages at the end of the section is not the way to do it.  If I add notes I do so in and around the recipe, not at the back of the section where I would forget about them.  And, there is plenty of space around the recipes in this book, so that to me I'm actually paying for 20 blank pages that I'll never use. <br /> <br />Oh, and I also have to agree with one reviewer that boiling an egg and dipping asparagus into it is NOT a recipe... <br /> <br />On the whole though, its a book I have enjoyed greatly because it has inspired me to approach cooking as relaxation, as something that should be intrinsically enjoyable, not a chore. <br />
0553573403|5.0|After the horror of reading Robert Jordan and wanting to tear my hair out at idea that popular fantasy lauded such mediocrity, I was very cautious picking up another book by an author for whom I'd heard nothing but endless praise.  When I started \\"A Game of Thrones\\", I knew just in reading the first few pages that George R.R. Martin wasn't just a popular, yet run of the mill writer, he is, in my opinion, a grand storyteller on a level of his own.  \\"A Game of Thrones\\" is not just an important work of fantasy, it is an essential work of fiction for anyone who adores a fast-paced, involved storyline.  In the first book of \\"A Song of Ice and Fire\\", Martin introduces his readers to the inevitiably tragic Stark family, who, thrust into the center of world-changing events, are ripped apart and scattered, each character, from eight year old Arya to her heart-hardened mother Catelyn, tells a tale which feeds into a larger picture.  Martin has meticulously crafted a story which involves personal relationships as well as warfare and politics, and though his world includes countless characters and details, each person holds his own within the book, and is a well-developed, believable entity.  These characters are Martin's masterpieces- and the author writes of them with love and empathy so that as his readers, we come to love them or hate them too.  \\"A Game of Thrones\\" is absolutely flawless fantasy, and \\"A Song of Ice and Fire\\" is an essential collection of popular fantasy for anyone who loves a great story.
006056492X|5.0|I think young people may have trouble understanding this book, which is about the experience of life. Told with great compassion, Vonnegut, in fact and in fiction both, is a mature man looking back on the tragedies he saw in his youth. Being \\"unstuck in time\\" can be seen as a metaphor for intrusive post-traumatic memories, and dissociated dreams, both of which happen to someone who has undergone great trauma. Vonnegut had the horror of his mother committing suicide when he was home on leave in WWII, and going from there to being a prisoner of war, seeing his friends shot and being forced to dig for rotting bodies in Dresden.  <br />  Ethan Hawkes does a superior job of reading the book, gentle and without irony. I recommend his audiobook. ( Although I think they put pictures of World War One soldiers on the cover for some strange reason. )
0393317552|4.0|The reviews of this seem to jump around from really positive to downright nasty. This strikes me as being more a measure of the reviewers' agendas then reasonable measures of the book. I come at it from the standpoint of a lay person, with no real knowledge about this topic but with the interest of a fairly intelligent person. As such, I find the book really compelling, thoughtful, interesting. Many of Diamond's theories make sense to me and I'm glad to have had them explained. He touches on so many things that there's something of interest for everyone. I bet that even the people who think this was \\"boring, boring, boring\\" have left it with ideas in their head that they wouldn't have had otherwise. This is the sort of book that you can't help mentioning again and again in casual conversation. That's what I love about it. It activates and spurs thoughts and makes one excited about knowledge. <br /> <br />The things I'm critical of aren't that big a deal. I don't always find Diamond easily readable. This book is somewhere between a popular book and a text book, but it's not exactly either. There are a lot of \\"as I mentioned in the previous chapter and will cover in more depth in chapter eight\\" sort of moments, and this can feel a bit repetive. Also, time and again he poses questions, talks about possible answers, then heads off on to the next thing. There's very little feeling of closure, except in the way he comes back again and again to his fundamental theories. <br /> <br />But anyway, if this topic interests you this book will not disappoint. I thank the author for writing it, and after I've let my mind drain a bit I'll probably pick up his new book, Collapse.
0440234743|4.0|I have to admit I wasn't thrilled with the last couple of John Grisham books. I picked up a copy of The Testament at a local library book sale for a twenty-five cents and thought about reading it. As I was driving home, I decided that if The Testament was similar to the last two, I would cross John Grisham off my list of favorite authors. I wasn't sure if his writing style had changed, or if it was just me changing what I want in a book; but either way, I didn't want to struggle through any more boring books. I guess you could say this was Grisham's last chance to keep me as an avid fan.<br /><br />I'm very thankful that I decided to give Grisham one more chance! In my opinion, this book is right up there with his all time greats, The Pelican Brief, Street Lawyer, etc.<br /><br />From the beginning the story of Troy Phelan grabs you and won't let go. Troy is a billionaire who is tired - tired of his family fighting among each other, tired of running his many companies, but most of all, tired of living. Troy plans to have all of his children from three previous marriages in his corporate headquarters for the signing of his last will and testament. Since his children believe he has a brain tumor and will soon be dividing up $ 11 billion, they are eager to attend. Each ex-wife and her children are seated in a different conference room separate from the other family members. Troy, his attorney, and three psychiatrists are in a conference room and video cameras transmit the proceedings. The psychiatrists are there to verify that Troy is of sound mind and therefore the last testament will stand up under any scrutiny. After the meeting breaks up, with cameras still rolling, Troy surprises everyone by producing a different will and testament, signs it and then leaps out the window to his death.<br /><br />As if this mess isn't enough fodder for the entire book, Grisham adds another dimension to the story. It seems that Troy has left the majority of his estate to an illegitimate daughter, Rachel Lane, a missionary in the Pantanal of Brazil. Nate O'Riley, a burned out attorney just out of rehab, is assigned by the firm handling Troy's estate to find Rachel. And so begins a journey that takes the reader through the wilderness of unspoiled Brazilian jungles. We're treated to glimpses of how life is lived in the jungles of Brazil, which brings the reader to wonder, if only for a moment, about our society and lifestyles. Grisham compares the Phelans who are all spoiled, greedy and corrupt to Rachel Lane, who's entire goal in life is to help the Indian tribe she's lived with for several years without what many would consider the necessities of life. It's definitely the old \\"good versus evil\\" plot but made enjoyable with various twists.<br /><br />Grisham has great character development and shows a knack for mixing intrigue with self-study. It does have its predictable aspects, but has enough mystery thrown in to keep the reader amused and entertained. With this book, we not only wonder if we are living life to its fullest, but also wonder about our ideals.legitimate daughter, Rachel Lane, a missionary in the Pantanal of Brazil. Nate O'Riley, a burned out attorney just out of rehab, is assigned by the firm handling Troy's estate to find Rachel. And so begins a journey that takes the reader through the wilderness of unspoiled Brazilian jungles. We're treated to glimpses of how life is lived in the jungles of Brazil, which brings the reader to wonder, if only for a moment, about our society and lifestyles. Grisham compares the Phelans who are all spoiled, greedy and corrupt to Rachel Lane, who's entire goal in life is to help the Indian tribe she's lived with for several years without what many would consider the necessities of life. It's definitely the old \\"good versus evil\\" plot but made enjoyable with various twists.  <br /> <br />Grisham has great character development and shows a knack for mixing intrigue with self-study. It does have its predictable aspects, but has enough mystery thrown in to keep the reader amused and entertained. With this book, we not only wonder if we are living life to its fullest, but also wonder about our ideals. <br />

WHAT YOU THOUGHT OF DAFT PUNK BEFORE NOW HAS COMPLETELY CHANGED.<br /><br />Ok back to the album.<br /><br />Basically after enjoying the success of Discovery, the French electric-pop duo decided to do another album.  Human after All, which is a total change from their happy-good times dance music.  Daft Punk's huge success with Discovery was I believe their lyrics, and the many different types of songs they created.  This album conversely does not have many spoken words at all.  Except for a couple repetitive songs with one lined words being repeated over and over again, this album practically has no words at all.  Except for the amazing spoken section on \\"Technologic\\".<br /><br />However, when you take away the peppy lyrics of discovery what are you left with.  Music.  Daft Punk in this album re-invents themselves musically by engaging guitars and powerfull chords into many of their new songs.  If Homework was their \\"dance\\" ablum, Discovery was their \\"happy\\" album, then this would be their \\"angry\\" album.  There is not one up-beat song on this album except for \\"Make love\\" and even that is darkened by powerfull chords.<br /><br />This album is not for those who loved \\"around the world\\" or \\"one more time\\", but for those who love the darker-heavy side Daft Punk.<br /><br />I highly doubt Leiji Matsumoto would want to make an anime musical to this album.<br /><br />Favorite tracks:<br /><br />Human after all, Robot rock, television rules the nation, technologic<br /><br />Least Favorite tracks:<br /><br />Emotion (EXTREMELLY REPETITIVE, BAD SONG FOR A CLOSER), the prime time of your life
B0000A118M|5.0|Where do I begin?  Trane surpasses our understanding with this work of art on record.  FULL of heartfelt expression of love, pain, desire, and a man who fully understands the what grace really is.  The album must be considered as a whole and not in parts.  It is one extended thought.  It is his relationship with God from beginning to end.  The hard times as well as the easy.  The omnipresence of God is in his notes.  There are studyings in Univeristy music classes on this one album.  There are books written on this one album.  Do not underestimate this album.  Do not merely listen to it; study it, analyze it, think about it.  Then pass it down to the next generation so that they will know and understand the greatest musical and artistic gift we've known.
B000002TYX|5.0|The Beatles- \\"Anthology 1\\" two disc set is an excellent purchase- for Beatlemaniacs. Beatles beginners should get their feet wet with a general career spanning best of set like \\"1\\" or \\"Past Masters\\". This is to spark initial interest with can't miss recordings. \\"Anthology 1\\" is for collectors. Many of the songs have inferior sound due to the fact they were shelved away and never officially recorded. However, the historic value of many of these tracks is remarkable. The Decca session recordings that were rejected are here. Two of the Beatles' first recordings done at Abbey Road studios are here, including a spicy cover of \\"Besame Mucho.\\" Other notable gems include 2 tracks recorded by the Beatles as the Tony Sheridan backing band when they lived in Germany, the early and best version of \\"One After 909\\" (it would later appear on the \\"Let it Be\\" record), and several recordings from the famous London Palladium show. And, you get the new track, \\"Free As a Bird,\\" which comes off as a solid yet unspectacular piece. All in all, \\"Anthology 1\\" is a great collectors item. The historical value in the recordings is significant. But it should also be noted that it is not a good starting point for those just stumbling into the Beatles' work because the numbers are often roughly recorded and aren't necessarily their best output. Highly recommended for Beatlemaniacs.

B000001GQY|5.0|With a bit of skepticism I purchased this CD based on guidance found here and from Gramophone, both endorsing this CD with lavish praise.  How could a recording be THAT good?  Believe me (and them)... it is simply breathtaking stuff.  Seldom does a CD capture such a magical combination of composition, interpretation and sound.  Before Beethoven's Fourth (Concerto) and Chopin's First shared the highest place of honor in my library.  No more.  Brahms' Second is magnificent music and it is with good reason that this particular recording is declared the sine qua non of its performances.  The product of Gilels' piano and the Berlin Philharmonic, under Jochum, is to savor as one would a fine meal or a good book.  The music commands you put down what you are doing and listen.  When it is over you want to hear it again.  The First is equally compelling, although I can fairly recommend Serkin (Szell/Cleveland on Sony Classics) and Curzon (Szell/London on Decca Legends) as admirable readings and strong contenders.  More than a mere \\"makeweight,\\" the Fantasien (Op. 116) are fine performances and a delightful change-of-pace from the \\"more serious\\" concertos.  Like so many before me, I have nothing but admiration and positives for this CD.

B0000CDL93|5.0|So, who do you believe???  Whether you think Stone is Satan or the Messiah, it's impossible to deny the power of this film.  I took the time to read all 243 previous reviews---that's how interested in this topic I am...  I'm impressed with the passion that you've all shown on this subject.  I'd love to tell you I was the second gunman on the grassy knoll, AND give you ALL irrefutable proof that it's the God's honest truth, but who would believe me?  Anyone who cares has already made up their mind.  What would it take (REALLY!) to get you to change your mind?  Have any of you ever thought about that???  I think that when I get to heaven, the first thing I'll ask is:  \\"What really happened on 11-22-63???\\"  But, for me, right now, in this life, I don't care any more about Oliver Stone than I do about Gerald Posner.  In fact, I would add those two to a list that also includes Walter Cronkite, Jim Garrison, Peter Travers, Dan Rather, Jim Marrs, Robert Groden, Earl Warren, Lyndon Johnson, Cyril Wecht and a sh#@load of others (Peter Jennings gets a special FU#@ YOU for his DUNGHEAD comment during a 40th anniversary TV special in 11/03), NONE OF WHOM I'D PISS ON EVEN IF THEY WERE ON FIRE.  How can you believe anyone at this point?  There's enough information out there to build a case for (practically) any theory you want.  I want the fu@#ing truth!!!  I can't believe that after this much time has passed that we still aren't any closer than we were in 1964.  The Warren Commission's investigation was a joke.  So many leads not followed, so many witnesses not interviewed, so many questions NOT ASKED, so many directions not taken...  Arlen Specter's work was pathetic.  He should be ashamed of himself for being that stupid or that naive, whichever is the case.  Humes burns the original draft of his autopsy notes (then later, gives a weak excuse for it), and nothing is done???  LBJ gets the limo cleaned and the interior replaced (BEFORE it can be inspected and photographed--HE DESTROYED EVIDENCE!!!), and nothing is done!!!  More than half the witnesses said they saw and/or heard shots from the grassy knoll/railroad area and the Warren Commission concentrates on those that said the shots came from the 6th floor window???  ALL the Dallas doctors said that the wounds clearly showed the shots came FROM THE FRONT,  but we're supposed to believe that they ALL MADE A MISTAKE and the monopoly on autopsy wisdom resides with the doctors at Bethesda???  A pathologist is 'chosen' to lead the autopsy who had NO (AUTOPSY) EXPERIENCE WITH VICTIMS OF GUNSHOT WOUNDS, and NO ONE DOES OR SAYS ANYTHING!!!  How the hell does something as important as the BRAIN get \\"lost\\"???  All this and more makes it obvious (to me) that there is no simple explanation for what happened.  Military/Industrial complex?  Cuba/Castro?  The Mob?  The CIA?  How 'bout the Secret Service?  Russia/KGB?  Oswald plus others?  How the hell are we supposed to know???  Reading everything that is out there just provides more suspects.  The real crime here is for those of us who are critical thinkers.  We know it's not a 'lone nut', but we're also skeptical of the myriad of other 'ideas' too.  I'm still reserving judgment in the (naive, I know) hope that more TRUTH will come to light before I die.
B0002OERI0|4.0|Were Green Day ever really 'punk', whatever that means? Dookie (which was not their debut by the way) had a lot of mid-tempo songs where the melody and meaning were the major aspect, and even the faster songs tended to be bouncy and catchy rather than particularly angry and heavy. I find the 'they've sold out' attitude disappointing, because these guys are in their 40s and should have matured by then. They've taken in different influences, written something unusual, varied and challenging. <br /> <br />Taking the tracks individually doesn't entirely sum the album up, but there are several which are distinctive. Making the title track the first single might've been a misjudgment, because it's not the most accurate representation of the album, being extremely angry and venemous - and certainly off-putting to anyone of Republican leanings. It's one of the stronger songs, but it's only one string to the band's bow. <br /> <br />At the opposite extreme we have Wake Me Up When September ends, a power ballad about Billie Joe remembering his father's death. While it's not up there with contemplative rock classics such as One by Metallica or All Apologies by Nirvana, it packs a real emotional punch and the vocals are stronger than you can ever expect. <br /> <br />The highlights of the album, for me, are Holiday and Letterbomb, both of which combine the bounce and anger of old with the lyrical structure and inspirational qualities the new Green Day aim for. Lyrics such as \\"I beg to dream and differ from the hollow lies\\" sum up the feelings of a generation in an articulate way, and ought to be as significant to those who can't understand youth rebellion as a concept. <br /> <br />The concept structuring was a big risk, and surely the reason why the album took 4 years. It's largely successful, telling the tale of a young man's attempts to break free, and his ultiamte failure to make an impression for all his efforts. Elements of this overlap with the seminal Zen Arcade by Husker Du, but this is far more accessible and wide-reaching (and therefore a 'sell-out', presumably?). The five-part tracks worek quite well, although the second one plods a little bit musically. <br /> <br />While I can't regard this as an all-time classic, or a match for the best tracks on Dookie, it really doesn't deserve the criticism it seems to have recieved from elements of all sides. It's not pop, it's not punk, it's not a sell-out, it's not a revolution, it's not the greatest record ever made, it's just a very good rock album.

B0001Z37HM|3.0|Director Richard Fleischer derailed the Conan movie franchise by making the 1984 \\"Conan the Destroyer\\" much more of a campy adventure than John Milius did with the original 1982 \\"Conan the Barbarian.\\" However, for this 1985 Conan spin-off of a Robert E. Howard inspired creation, the warrior-woman Red Sonja. In the title role is the statuesque model Brigitte Nielsen, making her film debut, with Arnold Schwarzenegger playing Kalidor, the Conan-clone who plays a pivotal supporting role in that he usually only shows up to save the film's heroine. However, given the idea that Red Sonja has been given her warrior strength to avenge the murder of her family and her own violent rape, the idea that a man has to keep bailing her own clearly runs against the character's ideology (and you just cannot ignore that sort of thing when the title character has been empowered by the gods as long as she keeps true to her vows and avoids sex).<br /><br />Arnold is a more engaging character this time around, which is rather easy since nobody is as sullen as Conan, and this is the first time where you really get a sense of fun in one of his movies (his serious resume at that point was the two Conan films and the first \\"Terminator\\"). The problem is that by the time he first shows up the best part of the movie is over, and for every decent moment provided by Arnold there are three or four scenes with Ernie Reyes, Jr. as the annoying Prince Tarn, reducing the movie to something like \\"Home Alone\\" with swords. The plot for \\"Red Sonja\\" involves a quest for a giant green orb and an evil queen (Sandhal Bergman), which makes it a lot like \\"Conan the Destroyer.\\" Indeed, the worst thing I can say about this sword and sorcery effort is that it made me like the Conan sequel a whole lot better, which is not whatt I was hoping for at all.<br /><br />One of the reasons we are surprised by how bad of a film we are watching is that the crew includes cinematographer Giuseppe Rotunno and art director Danilo Donati, who usually worked with Federico Fellini, and the music is by Ennio Morricone, who did all of the epic scores for Sergio Leone's spaghetti westerns. I know that neither one of those two celebrated directors would have touched this project, but one of their assistant directors could have turned in a more competent performance that Fleischer. \\"Conan the Barbarian\\" remains the best Sword & Sorcery film to date, and with his two entries Fleischer gets the lion share of credit for sending the whole genre right done the tubes. Milius is planning a King Conan movie for 2005, so there is hope, but those faintly flickering flames have gotten really small in the last twenty years.nilo Donati, who usually worked with Federico Fellini, and the music is by Ennio Morricone, who did all of the epic scores for Sergio Leone's spaghetti westerns. 1401201911|3.0|Mark Millar comes up with a simple but interesting idea for \\"Superman: Red Son.\\"  What if the rocket ship carrying the infant Kal-el from Krypton landed in the Ukraine rather than in Kansas?  The idea of Superman wearing a hammer and sickle rather than a big \\"S\\" and standing next to Joseph Stalin on top of Lenin's tomb is certainly captivating.  The problem with \\"Red Son\\" is that Millar takes this idea and goes way too far in finding variations on virtually every significant element of the Superman mythos.<br /><br />I was a bit concerned when this story did not begin with Superman being raised by his Soviet parents on a collective in the Ukraine.  It was not just that Superman landed in America, but that he was found by the Kents.  How they raised him was more important than where he was raised, and Millar skips over that part.  Having President Eisenhower announce that the Soviets had Superman was a nice touch, transferring the paranoia about Sputnik from that period to the threat of a Soviet Superman.  But then there was Millar's reworking of the introduction to television's \\"Superman,\\" which describes the strange visitor from another world who, \\"as the champion of the common worker, fights a never-ending battle for Stalin, Socialism, and the International Expansion of the Warsaw Pact.\\"<br /><br />Millar does not just throw the kitchen sink in with this one, but pretty much every other fixture he can find.  Lois Lane is still a reporter for the \\"Daily Planet\\" but is married to Lex Luthor, the scientific genius of the age.  Wonder Woman shows up and this world has its own Batman on that side of the Iron Curtain and Green Lantern on this side.  There is also a point where you are going to be thinking Frank Miller's \\"The Dark Night Returns\\" than the original story by Jerry Siegel & Joe Shuster.  There are just so many changes here that keeping track of all of them and figuring out how they are coming into play in the story.  Ultimately, it is not that the Soviet Superman is most different here, but rather Lex Luthor without any rational justification other than the dictates of simple role reversal.  Superman landing in the Ukraine would make him Soviet rather than American, but what turned Lex Luthor into the guy who makes Albert Einstein feel stupid?<br /><br />This three-part comic book story is penciled by Dave Johnson & Kilian Plunkett and inked by Andrew Robinson & Walden Wong.  There are a series of \\"posters\\" extolling the \\"Comrade of Steel\\" in the introduction, but that style is extended in part to the storytelling itself.  A story about a Soviet Superman drawn in the style of Soviet propaganda art appeals to me, especially since I think this one really needed to look different to sell the story and a specific artistic style was clearly available to be emulated.<br /><br />\\"Saturday Night Live\\" did a skit once where Superman landed in Nazi Germany and used his x-ray vision to identify circumcised spies trying to get to Hitler.  That skit had a simple elegance that \\"Superman: Red Son\\" could use more of that approach.  Part of my problem is that I had a strong expectation that Stalin would have used Superman to not just end but rather to win the Cold War, and I was expecting that it was in subjugating the United States and the rest of the West that Superman would experience a crisis of conscience over his Proletarian ideals and the execution of a Soviet master plan for world dominance.  Less would have been more here, and there is a sense in which this story end, in a manner of speaking, where it needed to have begun to tell this variation on the familiar tale.oviet Superman is most different here, but rather Lex Luthor without any rational justification other than the dictates of simple role reversal.  Superman landing in the Ukraine would make him Soviet rather than American, but what turned Lex Luthor into the guy who makes Albert Einstein feel stupid? <br /> <br />This three-part comic book story is penciled by Dave Johnson & Kilian Plunkett and inked by Andrew Robinson & Walden Wong.  There are a series of \\"posters\\" extolling the \\"Comrade of Steel\\" in the introduction, but that style is extended in part to the storytelling itself.  A story about a Soviet Superman drawn in the style of Soviet propaganda art appeals to me, especially since I think this one really needed to look different to sell the story and a specific artistic style was clearly available to be emulated.     <br /> <br />\\"Saturday Night Live\\" did a skit once where Superman landed in Nazi Germany and used his x-ray vision to identify circumcised spies trying to get to Hitler.  That skit had a simple elegance that \\"Superman: Red Son\\" could use more of that approach.  Part of my problem is that I had a strong expectation that Stalin would have used Superman to not just end but rather to win the Cold War, and I was expecting that it was in subjugating the United States and the rest of the West that Superman would experience a crisis of conscience over his Proletarian ideals and the execution of a Soviet master plan for world dominance.  Less would have been more here, and there is a sense in which this story end, in a manner of speaking, where it needed to have begun to tell this variation on the familiar tale.
1594200106|5.0|It is rare to come across a book that stands out from the crowd.<br /><br />This book does just that with its originality, etheral plot, haunting tone and revealing characters.<br /><br />The story follows a young boy resolved to hang onto the past, when the door to his journey opened by his ecentric father reveals a new reality, with danger and intrigue included, which the boy is compelled to conquer, so that he may finally embrace and release his past.
B0007OCG4W|4.0|We can't handle the truth when it comes to a relationship. Yet, we yearn for it. We try so desperately to get it out of the one we love that when we do succeed, it's often a nightmare. How well do we really know each other? Do we ever stop looking for love after we find it? Why do we always hurt the ones we love? Those questions are the basis for Mike Nichols' \\"Closer\\", a film about casual betrayals between our loved ones. \\"Closer\\" comprises of some pretty unpleasent things but you have to agree that it's nearly accurate. <br />As for the acting, Julia Roberts (who could have been better) does OK. Jude Law's role is somewhat similar from his past roles but still manages to give a solid preformance. It's no wonder who the stand outs are. Natalie Portman proves that she's capable of handling herself in all situations most notably where she shares a scene in a strip club with Clive Owen's character. It's both daring and impressive. Clive Owen is of course another other stand out. He probably has the best line in the film, \\"Have you ever seen a human heart? It looks like a fist wrapped in blood!\\" This brings me to another great stand out; the dialogue. Since it was originally written for the stage, most of the dialogue is acted out very theatrically which some viewers may love or hate. Anyone who watches the film will get something different out of it. B000000OS2|5.0|This is the unplugged album of all unplugged albums. It was the risk-taker that worked out. It was the one that established the trend and so rarely gets the credit it deserves for that.  It is the one that Rolling Stone forgets when they compile their lists of &quot;important&quot; albums.<br />They render some of their own tunes real well in this, like Heaven's Trail, The Way It Is, and Love Song. The crowd interaction for Gettin' Better makes you really feel you are there in the middle of the crowd. It does take some getting used to though when listening to Modern Day Cowboy as an unplugged version, but it works. <br />What is impressive are some of the takes they have on classic tunes. The Beatle's We Can Work it Out is stunning.  The Stones' Mother's Little Helper is a fun take. Five Man Electrical Band's song Sign was of course the big hit of this album that made a lot of people do a double-take to the possibilities of unplugged renderings.<br />Also included are a couple of Tesla jams in Tommy's Down Home, which has some hysterically funny lyrics sung by Tommy Skeoch, as well as Down Fo' Boogie which is also fun.

B000002HRE|2.0|I have been a fan of Metallica for only about 7 months. I first heard \\"Ride the Lightning\\" and \\"Master of Puppets\\" and was amazed. Since then I have gotten every album up to the Black Album and have been blown away by each one. I had heard that starting with \\"Load,\\" the quality of Metallica's albums had dropped, so I put off getting \\"Load\\" and \\"Reload,\\" while I vowed never to get \\"St. Anger.\\" Well, curiosity got the best of me and I bought \\"Load\\" and \\"Reload\\" at the same time. The numerous bad reviews both on this site and by professional critics did not prepare me for what I heard. I have made three guesses as to what happened to Metallica, and here they are: <br /> <br />1. (Putting the best construction on these albums) THEY DIDN'T WANT TO REPEAT THEMSELVES- If this is the case, you have to give Metallica credit, even though the experiment failed. They did not want to become an AC/DC, who has released nothing relevant since \\"Thunderstuck\\" about 20 years ago. AC/DC has stuck to pretty much the same formula that got them fans in the first place. Maybe Metallica wanted to keep their sound new, so if this is the case, fans should not be mad at Metallica for trying something new. <br /> <br />2. THEY ARE DOING WHAT THEY HAVE ALWAYS DONE- At the time of these releases, Alterna-metal and country were huge, so Metallica decided, \\"why not combine the two for a new sound?\\" After all, they took the two kings of the early eighties, hardcore punk and heavy metal, and combined them to produce thrash. They continued to produce heavy metal while heavy metal was still insanely popular. Now that the two genres mentioned at the beginning are popular, Metallica decided that they wanted to remain a relevant force in the music business instead of \\"Fading to Black\\" like most of thrash and even heavy metal bands of the eighties. <br /> <br />3. THEY DECIDED THAT THEY WERE MUSICAL GODS- They figured that no matter what they would spit out, they their fans would like it. In other words, their egos got too big. That would explain Hetfield actually singing here instead of his trademark growl. He decided that since he sounded great singing on \\"Nothing Else Matters,\\" (and he really did, he wasn't wrong about that) that he could just sing all of his songs and have them sound great. He seems to have forgotten that the reason that he started using the growl in the first place was BECAUSE he couldn't sing. Metallica has also decided that what they have to say is more important than the actual songs themselves, which would explain the lack of heavy riffs or outstanding solos. With \\"Master\\" and \\"Ride\\" the lyrics were as much of an art as the music was. That was most of the reason that Metallica ruled, because they were the only ones with \\"intelligent thrash\\" while everyone else was singing about Satan and evil. The worst part of all this is that Metallica didn't have that much to say, some of the lyrics just plain suck. With nothing to sing about, it is hard to make a good album (the same problem that Ozzy's Ozzmosis had). <br /> <br />As for the actual album, to be able to appreciate it, you must have an open mind. They still include a bunch of their trademark hooks, which makes the songs somewhat more bearable for me. \\"The Memory Remains\\" is just a watered down \\"The God That Failed.\\" Using Marianne Faithful was a clever trick. Even though her voice is terrible, I'm guessing alcohol, critics have a soft spot for her. Many critics upped their rating for this album just because she was on it (Can you believe she is still putting out albums with that terrible voice?!). I'll let you decide which of the three above was in Metallica's heads when they wrote this, but only fans of alterna-metal or maybe southern rock will be able to enjoy this (I am neither).

B000068FUS|4.0|Principle singer songwriter for the Drive By Truckers, Hood, makes several references to the duality of the Southern thing on an album he claims took 6 plus years to write and record.  What he never mentions, though, is the duality of Southern Rock Opera.  Like most people, I was blown away by this album.  I'm not (by an stretch of the imagination) a Southern rock afficiano, but enjoy The Allmans, Little Feat, early REM, current southern rock like My Morning Jacket, and even Skynyrd on occasion.  I was thrilled that this took many of the best parts of all those bands.  Unfortunately, the schtick of \\"Southern Rock Opera\\" wears a bit thin and hasn't aged as well as you would expect, even after a mere three years. <br /> <br />The duality of THIS Southern thing is it pulls off an almost unheard of musical hat-trick.  Sounds like a masterpiece first few times around, then reveals its true nature - a great bar band playing a Skynyrd tribute in more than just name.  It comes off with repeated listens as ameaturish.  That's not to say the album is bad.  Certainly not. B000008M54|5.0|I don't know how I overlooked this gem when I compiled my Amazon list of the 25 best albums of the 1980's, because it was definitely one of my favorites of the decade, and it remains one of the favorites of my personal collection.  It's the best album from Mike Scott and company, nearly perfect in every way, with an often bombastically big sound (one of the band's trademarks). Yet it's a very organic record, relying primarily on acoustic instruments, including some very capable fiddle work from Steve Wickham (especially on the hard-driving \\"We Will Not Be Lovers\\").  And it wears its Irishness on its sleeve.  The engaging title track may be familiar, as it has been used more than once in movie soundtracks.  And there's an awful lot more to like here, from a masterful cover of countryman Van Morrison's \\"Sweet Thing\\", to more traditional-sounding tunes like \\"When Will We Be Married?\\", to a heartbreakingly beautiful musical treatment of the Yeats poem, \\"The Stolen Child\\".  This is one of those albums I revisit every once in a while to remind myself how wonderful it was.  And it still is.

B000003TBP|5.0|\\"Odelay\\" is the album that established Beck as a superstar, and for good reason. It's an adventurous, yet insanely catchy melange of genres loaded with pop hooks and samples galore. <br /> <br />From the trigger-fuzz blues/rock/pop of \\"Devil's Haircut\\" to the resigning, affecting folk of \\"Ramshackle\\", and everything in between..you never know what will pop out next. <br /> <br />\\"Novacane\\" goes from Texas to New York in its course, seemlessly blending bluesey passages with hyper white noise and computer blips. \\"The New Pollution\\" has this turbelent, 1950's black & white pop feel, with commercial-esque interludes and stylish, jazzy saxophone samples.  <br /> <br />In terms of sampling, \\"High 5\\" puts everything else to shame; the dancefloor/raucous hip-hop number even samples a previous track from the album. How wacky is that? \\"Where It's At\\" is also a massive collage, and surely one of the most unlikely pop hits in recent years. <br /> <br />Other highlights include the heartbreaking folk of \\"Jackass\\", the sugar rush indie-rock of \\"Minus\\", and the infectious twang-covered pop of \\"Sissyneck\\".  <br /> <br />In theory, the album is a total mess. But Beck's knack for crafting clever, catchy pop songs makes this cut and paste job stick together and work a good 95% of the time.
6304056958|5.0|THE WOMEN, Clare Boothe Luce's blistering all-female comedy, has lost none if little of it's hilariously catty humour, more than half a century since it was originally released.  George Cukor directs the picture which stars almost every single female performer who was signed to MGM at the period.<br /><br />Mary Haines (Norma Shearer) discovers that her husband is having an affair with money-hungry perfume counter girl Chrystal Allen (Joan Crawford).  Aided and abetted by her cousin Sylvia Fowler (Rosalind Russell) and her army of girlfriends, Mary sets out to win back her man...and teach Chrystal a lesson or two in the process!<br /><br />Other main roles are taken by Joan Fontaine as the meek little Peggy Day, Paulette Goddard as  wisecracking Miriam Aarons, Lucile Watson as Mary's wise mother and Mary Boland as the hilarious Countess DeLave (who keeps wandering around ruefully talking about \\"l'amour\\"!).  Virginia Weidler plays Mary's daughter.<br /><br />George Cukor earned his reputation as a \\"woman's director\\" thanks to this film, and while he was exceptional in drawing out thrilling performances from his leading ladies (Ingrid Bergman in GASLIGHT springs to mind), he was also no slouch in directing men.<br /><br />The Technicolor 'fashion parade' sequence is quite gimmicky and drags the pace of the film down; indeed it does nothing to advance the story.  However, this is just one small quibble.  THE WOMEN is a comedic masterpiece and justifiably so.

The movie recognizes there is more than just becoming aware of and controlling as many aspects of life as you can.  Donnie chooses his own death in order to save his girlfriend not because it his simply the path he chooses, but because it is one of those moments that in the words of the movie \\"reminds you beautiful the world can be.\\"  In the end, I think the movie instead affirms that there is a best way of living with the choices that we have.

B0006399FS|5.0|Let's face it. Some people don't know any better. I suppose that it is not surprising that so many characters have stood up to put down \\"How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb.\\" Astonishing.With the better than 95 percent musical trash that constantly barrages the senses, it must be difficult to register a musical masterpiece on one's radar when it finally comes. Or maybe it's just that some people enjoy the sense of power that comes from indiscrimately criticizing without first taking the time to really listen and understand what they are listening to before they trot off to listen to the latest derivative rock crap.  If truth be told, I have never been a die-hard U2 fan. But there is a fine wine here. You savor its nuances; its entrancing, affecting melodies, its broad musical landscape and then you just drink it in and savor it some more, acquiring with each listening, a musical experience that just never leaves you. But first, you have to dump the sickenly sweet (or just numbingly pessimistic) commercial pop drinks that so many of us have become pathetically addicted to. U2's new album is testimony that there is still hope on the musical horizon. Love, peace, grief, angst, confusion, boundless joy. That's what's life is all about. The lads from Ireland have crafted yet another musical masterpiece for the ages and it ain't no PopMart. No one will remember much from next year's other Grammy winners 20 years from now. But they will remember this one.
B0007QJ1MK|4.0|First impressions count.This may be true in many ways,but my ears have required a softly softly approach to this new addition to the QOTSA reputable catalogue of masterpieces.  <br />It seems that a high proportion of their loyal subjects were honouring the partnership of Homme and Oliveri but this clearly isn't the catalyst of the Stone Age sound.The signature on/off-beat & obscure guitar is firmly in place and it seems that Homme's more interested in experimenting with the partnership of guitar & vocals rather than the bass/guitar duel of the previous incarnations.Perhaps it can be said that the playful,spoilt-kid attitude that Oliveri brought into the mix is a sad departure,but this album hangs together with maturity & confidence.The fact that MarkLanegan has secured the opening 'lullaby' with his melancholia,suggests that despite his absence from the rest of the album,he is it's 'godfather'. <br />Of course,there is the muso-mate/girlfriend collaboration in the forms of Brody Dalle & Shirley Manson who add \\"sultry vocals\\" on the eerie \\"You got a killer scene there,man\\".But it's ZZ Top's Billy Gibbons who is the real guest of honour.His musical donations are unmistakable on Burn The Witch,& the bonus track Precious & Grace.With a homage to Sabbath,he effortlessly commands the mic & gives it some dirty Texan groove.Even though he seems to have missed the bus for the ego trip,Homme really commands the performance.He's created a mix of  experimental compositions which edge towards the dark-side,typified on Someone's In The Wolf & Blood Is Love,& own-brand catchy,riff-rich staples like Dressed Up In Plaid & Everybody Knows That You're Insane.The obvious single is In My Head with it's sing-a-long chorus,but the first release,Little Sister is perhaps the only other track which fits the commercial bill.Broken Box could be the song that never made the cut on Rated-R,& Skin on Skin has a perverse feel which is a distinct nod to Mudhoney.Long Slow Goodbye bids us a bluesyfarewell with a sinister Carmina Burana style finale.After listening to these 'Lullabies',paralysis isn't a problem.What's bothering me is the whereabouts of 'The Fun Machine Took A Sh** & Died',the 'misplaced' track of which we have been robbed Perhaps it's a cryptic sleeve-note tribute - the so-called 'Fun Machine' being a metaphor for the departed Oliveri.If this is the case,let the 'Fun-Machine' RIP.Long live QOTSA.   <br />

B0007QJ1MK|2.0|Well let me start by saying that i have been a Queens fan ever since the Kyuss days, and that this album is by no means total crap. i'd say it merits three stars as a regular album, but coming from the same man that gave us Sky Valley, Blues for the Red Sun and countless other classics, this album is simply too tame for my liking. The production is perfect to the point of annoyance, and the whole work is centred on Homme's current style. What I love about the queens last two albums, SFTD and Rated R, is their intense diversity - losing Nick took away part of that breadth that their music contained. This album seems bland in comparison to the other two albums. The Queens are in a long decline (unlike the desert sessions and mondo generator), becoming more and more narrow minded with each album they make. Homme seems to have got his head stuck so far up his own arse that he's forgotten that all songs need not sound the same. Having said that, the opening Mark Lanegan track is fantastic, In my head is great (better on the desert sessions), but the album lacks any true standouts in my opinion. The guests are quite good if somewhat portentuously presented. Part of the charm of the desert sessions is that Homme allowed others in on the work, it was more of a group effort. This album feels more like a bunch of people adding to Homme's work, which is not what the queens were originally about. A damn shame, cause this is the first album of theirs that i have truly disliked. Sorry Josh!

6305078491|4.0|I think there's a weird kind of disconnect for modern audiences when they watch a silent film, and despite the fact that Carl Theodor Dreyer's Vampyre is in fact a \\"talkie\\", I don't think any movie could illustrate the point better.<br /><br />Sound in motion pictures was new enough when this film was made that the film-makers were clearly adjusting to the idea. Dialogue is minimal, sound effects are sparse enough to be jarring, and most of the movie plays like some victorian goth kid's fever dream. The combination of minimal sound and beautiful and atmospheric visuals make for something very unique and unsettling. Definitely worth watching.<br /><br />Hard-core vampire fans should be warned: despire the title,<br /><br />this movie is more of a haunted house story than a vampire story. If you're dying for vintage bloodsucking, you should probably check out that other 1931 vamipre movie. You know, the one starring the Romanian guy from Seasme Street.
0440217563|3.0|I keep saying that I don't like these books, but I keep reading them! So Gabaldon must be doing something right. Voyager, in particular, is refreshing because, in this youth-crazed world, it shows that love and passion are not the sole province of the under-40. However, as with the first two books in the series, several disturbing elements keep cropping up and leaving a bad taste in my mouth. To quote the late Ann Landers, Gabaldon seems to have \\"a geranium in her cranium\\" on certain topics, to wit: <br />1. Homosexuality. Jamie encounters yet another English prison governor hot for his body in the person of Lord John Grey. Gabaldon may be trying to overcome the accusations of homophobia generated by her portrayal of the sadistic Jonathan Randall in Outlander by making Grey a sympathetic character, but still, it was a bit much! Why is Jamie such a guy magnet? And what of his own somewhat ambivalent response, which carries over from Outlander to this installment? He is seemingly repulsed by Grey's advances, but later (I won't give it away) acts in a somewhat inconsistent manner in this regard. Is our Jamie secretly AC/DC? Gabaldon flirts with this issue in a very weird way. <br />2. Physical punishment. Once again, we are treated to a detailed flogging scene, though not quite as long as the similar scenes in Outlander. And once again, there is an erotic component to the scene as Grey watches from the window. Gabaldon intertwines physical punishment and love (both erotic and parental) in a very unsettling way. There is much discussion of the impending beating of Jamie's nephew, Ian, by his father, a task which Jamie undertakes himself because he got the lad in trouble in the first place. Again, this is described with relish and at great length, followed by a similarly detailed description of Jamie submitting himself to a beating by Ian, the whole depicted as a kind of bonding experience. Creepy. (And I have never been able to forgive Jamie for his beating of Claire inOutlander, or to excuse her for letting him get away with it--and, once again, Gabaldon portrayed the beating as a turning point in her growing to love him). <br /> <br />If Gabaldon dropped these themes from subsequent installments of this series, it could only improve what is basically fun, escapist entertainment.
